AD_DiscussingMarcus.synopsis: Jaheira discusses the outing of Marcus as a traitor with another Harper. Marcus is unaware he's been exposed at this stage so they discuss sotto voce.

AD_AtCheckpoint.synopsis: Jaheira is waiting for the return of her scouts. On edge.

AD_Attention.synopsis: Jaheira draws the player's attention by calling to them.
AD_Attention.how_to_trigger: Start SCL_Main_AGo to Haven checkpoint Pass Haven checkpointApproach Jaheira.

MeetsHalsin.synopsis: Halsin and Jaheira conversation to catch them not being a true soul like she's looking for. Instead they have a civil conversation, but bearly do more than scratch the surface

individual_metadata.synopsis: Default Jaheira dialog, not specific to any one situations. Contains quest updates for defeating Ketheric, and background lore on numerous other questions.
individual_metadata.how_to_trigger: Resolve HAV_EnteringHaven_TadpoleCheckpoint - speak to Jaheira at her customary spot in the inn.

AD_PlayersAttackJaheira.synopsis: Jaheira calls all of the Harpers in the Haven to fight if you choose to attack them as part of the Entering Haven situation
AD_PlayersAttackJaheira.how_to_trigger: When you first approach the gates of Haven, move through the dialog until Jaheira releases you from the vine sbecause of either Mol or Marcus's intervention. Then select the Attack dialog option.

automatic_ordering.reasoning: Looking at the session synopses and trigger hints, we notice a few points. First, the AD_Attention session is clearly meant to be triggered at the initial approach to Haven – it is the call that gets the player’s attention – and from its trigger instructions it happens before the later, more general or consequence‐style dialogs. In particular, the default Jaheira dialog (with the empty key) is triggered only after resolving the Haven tadpole checkpoint (i.e. after the initial encounter), so we can say that AD_Attention should precede the default dialog. In some cases, if the player hesitates or if time passes, another session – AD_AtCheckpoint (“Jaheira is waiting for the return of her scouts. On edge”) – may be activated later, so it makes sense to have AD_Attention come first and then AD_AtCheckpoint if that branch is reached. In addition, there is an option where the player “attacks” Jaheira at the Haven gates; the AD_PlayersAttackJaheira session is triggered only when the player selects the attack option. Since the initial dialog (AD_Attention) is part of the approach, the attacking branch (AD_PlayersAttackJaheira) can only occur after encountering AD_Attention. Moreover, once the player chooses to attack, the normal conversational track (that would lead to the default Jaheira dialog) will not be available. Hence, AD_PlayersAttackJaheira and the default conversation (the empty key session) are mutually exclusive. The other sessions (AD_DiscussingMarcus, OutOfPosition, AD_CombatTaunts, and MeetsHalsin) do not provide clear cause–effect or branching constraints relative to these particular checkpoint and branch triggers, so they are left aside from ordering or exclusiveness constraints.

AD_DiscussingMarcus_0.speaker: Harper Callie
AD_DiscussingMarcus_0.text: Do you think any of the other Flaming Fist are compromised?

AD_DiscussingMarcus_1.speaker: Jaheira
AD_DiscussingMarcus_1.text: Just Marcus. At least that's what our new friend tells me.

AD_DiscussingMarcus_2.speaker: Jaheira
AD_DiscussingMarcus_2.text: Cultists, fiends, and now a traitor in our midst. Some things never change.

AD_DiscussingMarcus_3.speaker: Jaheira
AD_DiscussingMarcus_3.text: Listen. Marcus is a traitor. He's with the Absolute. We have to be ready to move in before he can stage an attack.

AD_DiscussingMarcus_4.speaker: Harper Callie
AD_DiscussingMarcus_4.text: We've been infiltrated? Thank the gods you found him out. Give the order. I'm with you.

AD_DiscussingMarcus_6.speaker: Harper Callie
AD_DiscussingMarcus_6.text: But what does Marcus want? What's his target?

AD_DiscussingMarcus_5.speaker: Jaheira
AD_DiscussingMarcus_5.text: Haven't you noticed how close an eye he keeps on Isobel? Think about it: no Isobel, no Last Light.

AD_DiscussingMarcus_7.speaker: Harper Callie
AD_DiscussingMarcus_7.text: Isobel... of course! We have to apprehend him now, before he can strike.

OutOfPosition_0.speaker: Jaheira
OutOfPosition_0.text: Bear with me for a moment, there are better places to talk.

OutOfPosition_1.speaker: Jaheira
OutOfPosition_1.text: I'm spreading word - quietly. Go and flush Marcus out. My Harpers and I will make sure he has nowhere to go.
OutOfPosition_1.context: NodeContext: Hushed, determined -  making a plan with you but trying not to raise alarm.

AD_CombatTaunts_0.speaker: Jaheira
AD_CombatTaunts_0.text: Serene she might seem, but nature has fangs!

AD_CombatTaunts_1.speaker: Jaheira
AD_CombatTaunts_1.context: NodeContext: A battle-cry from a previous game.

AD_CombatTaunts_2.speaker: Jaheira
AD_CombatTaunts_2.text: You are scarcely fit to feed the earth.

AD_AtCheckpoint_0.speaker: Jaheira
AD_AtCheckpoint_0.text: If you see movement, don't be too quick to shoot. Friend and foe look alike in the deep shadows.
AD_AtCheckpoint_0.context: NodeContext: speaking to and encouraging allies who are watching a defensive perimiter - on edge

AD_AtCheckpoint_1.speaker: Jaheira
AD_AtCheckpoint_1.text: Look for torch fire in the distance, but do not venture out. Wave the patrol over to safety.
AD_AtCheckpoint_1.context: NodeContext: speaking to and encouraging allies who are watching a defensive perimiter - on edge

AD_AtCheckpoint_2.speaker: Jaheira
AD_AtCheckpoint_2.text: They'll be back, don't you worry. Lighter than the dark, faster than the shadows - that is how they move.
AD_AtCheckpoint_2.context: NodeContext: speaking to and encouraging allies who are watching a defensive perimiter - on edge

AD_AtCheckpoint_3.speaker: Jaheira
AD_AtCheckpoint_3.text: They're taking their sweet time, aren't they, Harpers? Must be some good picnic spots out there.
AD_AtCheckpoint_3.context: NodeContext: speaking to and encouraging allies who are watching a defensive perimiter - on edge

AD_Attention_0.speaker: Jaheira
AD_Attention_0.text: Don't wander far - we need to talk.

MeetsHalsin_5.speaker: Jaheira
MeetsHalsin_5.text: The Archdruid Halsin. Do not be surprised that I know your name - you fit a rather singular description.

MeetsHalsin_14.speaker: Jaheira
MeetsHalsin_14.text: And one survivor of the shadow curse's fall ought to know another.

MeetsHalsin_21.speaker: Player
MeetsHalsin_21.text: We never actually got to meet, when fighting Ketheric that first time.

MeetsHalsin_25.speaker: Jaheira
MeetsHalsin_25.text: No. We were a host hundreds strong, after all. Until we were not.

MeetsHalsin_13.speaker: Player
MeetsHalsin_13.text: It is an honour to see you again, High Harper.

MeetsHalsin_17.speaker: Jaheira
MeetsHalsin_17.text: No need for titles. You may call me Jaheira, so long as you are content to be known as Halsin. And the honour is mine.

MeetsHalsin_4.speaker: Jaheira
MeetsHalsin_4.text: Your stewardship of the Emerald Grove has made for something of a story among the circles.

MeetsHalsin_6.speaker: Jaheira
MeetsHalsin_6.text: The apprentice who survived the shadow curse, and carried his masters home on his back. Who was raised their master in turn, and searches still for a way to save what was lost.

MeetsHalsin_16.speaker: Player
MeetsHalsin_16.text: No one who witnessed that battle is likely to forget it.

MeetsHalsin_7.speaker: Jaheira
MeetsHalsin_7.text: Not the battle, nor what came after.

MeetsHalsin_3.speaker: Jaheira
MeetsHalsin_3.text: Those of us who saw the birth of the shadow curse seem doomed to return, and bear witness to its work again.

MeetsHalsin_23.speaker: Jaheira
MeetsHalsin_23.text: But I ought to warn you, Halsin. Much as it shames me - it is not the curse I come to cleanse, but the cult.

MeetsHalsin_8.speaker: Player
MeetsHalsin_8.text: We owe a debt to this land. To finish what we started.

MeetsHalsin_0.speaker: Jaheira
MeetsHalsin_0.text: And I hope that we shall have that chance. But not at the expense of the world entire.

MeetsHalsin_18.speaker: Jaheira
MeetsHalsin_18.text: Then I'll pray for the Oakfather to raise the road before you, but my battle is with the Absolute.

MeetsHalsin_19.speaker: Player
MeetsHalsin_19.text: You don't have to explain yourself to me.

MeetsHalsin_1.speaker: Jaheira
MeetsHalsin_1.text: Don't I? We both left this land with a half-victory in hand at most - but only one of us settled for it.

MeetsHalsin_12.speaker: Jaheira
MeetsHalsin_12.text: It has become my way, perhaps, to always have one eye on the next fight. For better or worse, that is the cult.

MeetsHalsin_26.speaker: Jaheira
MeetsHalsin_26.text: Though I will not be the one to fight it, I think. The one you journey with - we ought to speak.

MeetsHalsin_15.speaker: Jaheira
MeetsHalsin_15.text: Though I will not be the one to fight it, I think. The one you journey with - we have already spoken of infiltrating Moonrise.

MeetsHalsin_20.speaker: Jaheira
MeetsHalsin_20.text: One carrying a tadpole - a True Soul - might be able to reach Ketheric. And then... perhaps we will find a way to fight both our battles.

MeetsHalsin_11.speaker: Jaheira
MeetsHalsin_11.text: Archdruid. May the Oakfather raise the road before you.

84.speaker: Jaheira
84.text: Traitors among us, a child taken... and still I can only feel relief. If they had taken Isobel too...
84.context: NodeContext: Bitter - a child was kidnapped because of her, and it still counts as a win because the 'important people' survived

124.speaker: Player
124.text: It's worse than you know. I have reason to believe that Isobel is Ketheric's daughter.

43.speaker: Player
43.text: We should have taken Marcus while we had the chance.

380.speaker: Jaheira
380.text: That was my failing. I thought to turn their trap to my advantage, and wound up snaring us all the tighter.

70.speaker: Player
70.text: You should have seen this coming.

106.speaker: Jaheira
106.text: I thought I was prepared for treachery. But an all-out assault... I blundered into their trap like a fool.

458.speaker: Jaheira
458.text: You have the honour of making up for my mistake.

391.speaker: Jaheira
391.text: Discover Ketheric's secret. Find out what it is that makes him invincible so we can strip him of his advantage.

474.speaker: Player
474.text: I saw Ketheric. He regenerated before my eyes.

411.speaker: Jaheira
411.text: Gruesome, isn't it? I'm glad you survived the encounter, at least.
411.context: NodeContext: Frustrated - bad news and she takes a beat to process it before speaking.

325.speaker: Player
325.text: Ketheric wants Isobel brought to him - that might be a way to get further inside.

356.speaker: Jaheira
356.text: Not an option. Even if Isobel were willing, the inn would not survive without her.
356.context: NodeContext: Firm shake of the head

193.speaker: Jaheira
193.text: But if Ketheric fears her... all the better. It means whatever he's planning can still be stopped.

421.speaker: Jaheira
421.text: Find what makes him vulnerable. It remains the only way.

160.speaker: Player
160.text: Not yet. Parts of the Towers aren't open to me yet.

436.speaker: Jaheira
436.text: The great General is paranoid. Good - that means he's protecting something.

397.speaker: Jaheira
397.text: I'll wager it's the source of his invulnerability. He'd protect that at any cost.

351.speaker: Player
351.text: Ketheric is calling himself a 'Chosen of the Absolute' now.

110.speaker: Jaheira
110.text: 'Chosen'. That's three masters Ketheric has served. Our paladin isn't very picky.

200.speaker: Jaheira
200.text: He's aligned himself with mind flayers, but I cannot see what he gains.

20.speaker: Jaheira
20.text: Perhaps we can force it out of him once we have him up against a wall.

197.speaker: Player
197.text: I wanted to ask you about something.

283.speaker: Player
283.text: I've heard your name before. Where?

125.speaker: Jaheira
125.context: NodeContext: Unfazed - she's a known hero but is bored by the renown more than anything

450.speaker: Jaheira
450.text: They have me slaying gods or laying with them, depending on the bard.

223.speaker: Player
223.text: I feel your pain - my companion Volo is loose with the truth too.

16.speaker: Jaheira
16.text: Volothamp Geddarm? That old fraud should be dust a century past.
16.context: NodeContext: Eyes narrowed, suspicious - we've just raised a name from well in her past. An ally, but an irritating one.

345.speaker: Jaheira
345.text: But then, lies live forever, and he's half-made of the stuff.

5.speaker: Jaheira
5.text: You'll have to sing that one for me, when all of this is done. In any case, it was a lifetime ago by now. And for all our victories, we remain on the back foot.

238.speaker: Jaheira
238.text: We fight, we die, and we just hope that when our time comes, there is someone else to take our place.

357.speaker: Player
357.text: Stirring words. Is that how you inspire your Harpers?

67.speaker: Jaheira
67.text: No need of that. Every Harper is a bard unto themselves, I'm afraid.

350.speaker: Jaheira
350.text: Help me root out this cult, and they can spin stories about you for a change.

374.speaker: Player
374.text: Surely you made more of a difference than that.

360.speaker: Jaheira
360.text: The songs would have you believe we saved the Realms entire. Perhaps we did.

461.speaker: Jaheira
461.text: They simply refuse to stay saved.

424.speaker: Jaheira
424.text: That remains to be seen. Criterion number one: make Ketheric bleed.

318.speaker: Jaheira
318.text: Criterion two: survive that thing in your skull.

205.speaker: Jaheira
205.text: There are as many versions of a tale as there are people to tell it. Let that satisfy you. And anyway, the heroics of old have done seemingly little to safeguard the present.

268.speaker: Player
268.text: You don't seem overly pleased to be remembered.

343.speaker: Jaheira
343.text: It was a lifetime ago. And for all our victories, the world is no more balanced than when we began.
343.context: NodeContext: Shrugging - there are legends around her and her friends, but to her it's in the past

270.speaker: Player
270.text: How did the Harpers first learn of the Absolute?

32.speaker: Jaheira
32.text: The same way Harpers learn of anything - poking noses where they don't belong.

324.speaker: Jaheira
324.text: We sent an agent to infiltrate this cult - the latest fad among the city's bored nobility, I thought.

445.speaker: Jaheira
445.text: Until that same agent returned and tried to plant a knife in my neck. My first encounter with a True Soul.

355.speaker: Jaheira
355.text: I am glad ours ended on friendlier terms.

29.speaker: Jaheira
29.text: From there, I made some inquiries of my own - saw first-hand how easily the cult could turn friend to foe, with but the twist of a tadpole.

426.speaker: Jaheira
426.text: And so I gathered my Harpers and came to the source - Moonrise Towers.

365.speaker: Jaheira
365.text: The Nightsong. Have you learned anything more?

305.speaker: Jaheira
305.text: Honesty will serve you better than charity. I blundered into their trap, and it cost us.

166.speaker: Player
166.text: Let's just focus on defeating Ketheric.

422.speaker: Jaheira
422.text: Agreed. We must end the threat at Moonrise altogether. With your help, we stand every chance of doing just that.

446.speaker: Player
446.text: I assume you have some payback in mind?

165.speaker: Jaheira
165.text: You know me already. But you'll have the honour of making up for my blunder here.

95.speaker: Jaheira
95.text: Isobel's in her room upstairs - she'll be expecting you.
95.context: NodeContext: Surveying us, happy to see us

440.speaker: Player
440.text: Jaheira, you should know - I have reason to believe Isobel could be a Thorm. Ketheric's daughter.

143.speaker: Player
143.text: Wait. there's a Flaming Fist upstairs - Marcus. He's a True Soul with plans to kidnap Isobel.

226.speaker: Jaheira
226.text: Marcus? If he'd managed to get himself infected without a single Harper noticing, I'd be... very surprised.

4.speaker: Jaheira
4.text: Is this meant to be some kind of joke?

184.speaker: Player
184.text: Absolutely not. Marcus is a danger to you all.

209.speaker: Jaheira
209.text: Let's be discreet about this. If Marcus is what you say, there's no telling what kind of reinforcements he might be able to summon.
209.context: NodeContext: Lowerign voice. She believes the player that Marcus is a spy.

152.speaker: Jaheira
152.text: All right. He's in Isobel's room upstairs. Play along with his ruse for now while I gather a few trusted Harpers - but don't let him get his hands on Isobel!

414.speaker: Jaheira
414.text: You did well bringing this to me - thank you.

100.speaker: Jaheira
100.text: A Harper's gaze can only be turned by proof. By the looks of it, a tall tale is all you have to offer.

306.speaker: Jaheira
306.text: You might be... eccentric, but you're still our best hope of finishing off Ketheric Thorm.

386.speaker: Player
386.text: I have proof, if you'll just come upstairs and look.

462.speaker: Player
462.text: Ignore me, then. It's your own funeral.

403.speaker: Jaheira
403.text: I'm not ignoring you - I just see no evidence of your rather outlandish claim.

218.speaker: Jaheira
218.text: You've come from the shadows and wasted no time accusing one of our companions of treason. It's all a little... odd.

99.speaker: Jaheira
99.text: There is a grave threat to us all, stretching as far as Baldur's Gate, and I need your help.

206.speaker: Jaheira
206.text: Traitors among us, and still I can only feel relief. If we had lost Isobel...
206.context:
NodeContext: Bitter - 
it still counts as a win because the 'important people' survived

373.speaker: Jaheira
373.text: You've got a Thorm to undo.
373.context: NodeContext: Surveying us, happy to see us

393.speaker: Player
393.text: I've been looking into Ketheric. I suspect Isobel might be his daughter.

387.speaker: Jaheira
387.text: Do you. Well, let us not leave you in suspense, then.

304.speaker: Player
304.text: You already knew. Why didn't you tell me?

257.speaker: Jaheira
257.text: Because it isn't my tale to tell. And because, in truth, I do not know the half of it. Only this:

36.speaker: Player
36.text: It's more than that. She was dead, and something brought her back.

174.speaker: Jaheira
174.text: Something malign? Or some blessing of Selûne, perhaps? I do not know what restored Isobel's life to her. But I can see what she is doing with it.

359.speaker: Player
359.text: And you trust her? She's all that stands between us and the shadow curse.

96.speaker: Jaheira
96.text: Exactly the point, wouldn't you say?

149.speaker: Jaheira
149.text: If she wished to see us drowned in darkness, Isobel needn't have lifted a finger. Instead, she holds out her hand.

127.speaker: Jaheira
127.text: I choose to take it. I choose to trust. And not just because I have no other choice.

41.speaker: Player
41.text: I tried to talk to her about it. She won't tell me anything.

168.speaker: Jaheira
168.text: Perhaps she chooses to do, rather than say.

472.speaker: Jaheira
472.text: When I find myself needing a reminder of just who Isobel Thorm is, I simply step outside and look up.

453.speaker: Player
453.text: I'll need to speak to her myself.

10.speaker: Jaheira
10.text: If it will help. Only remember:

471.speaker: Jaheira
471.text: I bear more blame for the shadow curse than Isobel does. And she can no more control her parentage than you can that thing in your head.

367.speaker: Jaheira
367.text: She'll extend that protection to you too, if you see her. You've shown me how well you can sniff out secrets - I'd like to see you turn that nose upon Ketheric Thorm.

389.speaker: Jaheira
389.text: Now. You've shown me how well you can sniff out secrets. It's time you turned that nose upon Ketheric, no?

239.speaker: Player
239.text: All right, then. Trust it is.

379.speaker: Jaheira
379.text: Then you're a stronger soul than I. I at least have had time to prepare that high-minded little speech. Still, if your faith ever wavers:

392.speaker: Player
392.text: 'Trust'? You tried to kill me the first time we met.

42.speaker: Jaheira
42.text: And now we are the best of friends. You see? The power of trust.

155.speaker: Jaheira
155.text: Look around you. You shall have to learn to live with 'not good enough', I'm afraid.

375.speaker: Player
375.text: Nothing new to report yet, but the search continues.

212.speaker: Jaheira
212.text: A search burdened by unnatural darkness, but don't let that discourage you.
212.context: NodeContext: One of Jaheira's famous lines from previous games; may want to google it for a reference. Here she is saying it to confirm that she will wait for news from the player.

176.speaker: Player
176.text: I've discovered the source of Ketheric's invulnerability: a woman called the Nightsong.

444.speaker: Player
444.text: Questions about Isobel? What do you mean?

307.speaker: Jaheira
307.text: You were the last to be alone with her. And just like that, she's gone.

40.speaker: Jaheira
40.text: If you had nothing to do with it - and I want to believe you didn't - you have nothing to fear from me.

417.speaker: Jaheira
417.text: Please, be welcome. Have a drink.
417.context: CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) We meet Jaheira standing by a table. On it are glasses of wine waiting for us.

394.speaker: Karlach
394.context: NodeContext: stage whisper in excitement to the player. she can't believe player is having a drink with jaheira

170.speaker: Jaheira
170.context: CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Jaheira raises a glass. She looks us in the eyes very intently.

199.speaker: Narrator
199.text: *You perceive a faint hint of Klauthgrass, a herb that is said to elicit the truth. Jaheira smiles at you knowingly.*
199.context: CinematicNodeContext: Player raises wine glass to their nose

368.speaker: Jaheira
368.text: It doesn't spoil the taste, if that's what you're wondering.

237.speaker: Player
237.text: I have to say, it's an honour to drink with you, ma'am. Cheers.

362.context: CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Jaheira empties the wine glass in one gulp. When she puts the glass down you can tell from her face she very much enjoyed the wine.

449.speaker: Jaheira
449.text: Well over a century old and yet it hasn't lost a hint of flavour.
449.context:
CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Introspectively. She’s equating herself with the wine.
NodeContext: Introspectively. She’s equating herself with the wine.

201.speaker: Jaheira
201.text: Still not quite so sure about you, though.

222.speaker: Jaheira
222.text: People tend to lose more than just flavour when illithids get their hands on them. I speak from experience.

401.speaker: Jaheira
401.text: There's an air about you. Something - alien.

134.speaker: Jaheira
134.text: Answer me true and do not lie: the parasite is changing you, isn't it?

150.speaker: Player
150.text: I see now why you spiked my wine.

454.speaker: Player
454.text: Yes. The parasite is giving me powers I never had before. It's changing me for the better.

196.speaker: Player
196.text: It controlled me once, but I am free of its influence now.

53.speaker: Player
53.text: It's trying to change me, to win me over, but I'm resisting its temptations.

465.speaker: Player
465.text: It's trying to change me, to win me over, but I'm resisting its temptations.

468.speaker: Player
468.text: It's trying to change me, to win me over, but I'm resisting its temptations.

267.speaker: Player
267.text: It's trying to change me, to win me over, but I'm resisting its temptations.

64.speaker: Jaheira
64.text: And you're certain you will continue to resist?

17.speaker: Jaheira
17.text: Good. I will take your word for it. And hold you to it, too.

141.context: CinematicNodeContext: Jaheira raises her arm like she did previously when she was about to summon her strangling vines. Her face hardens, but then -full of inner turmoil- she decides against it and lowers her arm again.

463.speaker: Jaheira
463.text: Look around you: good men, good women, stranded here - two feet in the grave.

45.speaker: Jaheira
45.text: If we're to survive, I have no choice but to trust you. Can I?

425.speaker: Player
425.text: You can, ma'am. I wouldn't lie to you.

335.speaker: Jaheira
335.text: You seem like a good kid. But I'm going to hold you to that - with my scimitar, if needed.

295.speaker: Jaheira
295.text: Good. Because I'll cross your heart myself if you break it.

112.speaker: Jaheira
112.text: I have every reason to be cautious. I've traced people like you, people with parasites in their brains, all the way here from Baldur's Gate.

3.speaker: Jaheira
3.text: The cult of the Absolute is spreading through the city - quietly, quickly, and with unsettling deliberation.

404.speaker: Jaheira
404.text: We tracked them to this ancient village only to be faced with a man we killed and buried over a century ago.

382.speaker: Player
382.text: Ketheric Thorm. He and I have history.

94.speaker: Player
94.text: Ketheric Thorm. I encountered him in Moonrise Towers.

158.speaker: Jaheira
158.text: You were the one who rescued those the Absolute had imprisoned. You were courageous to brave the depths of Ketheric's stronghold.

183.speaker: Jaheira
183.text: I suppose you know about Ketheric, then. His invincibility. That we'll never cleanse this place until he's made to bleed.

213.speaker: Jaheira
213.text: You've been to the Towers? Incredible. Your parasite has already served you well.

320.speaker: Jaheira
320.text: The one and only. He was a Sharran, then. We caught him building an army of Dark Justiciars. With the local druids, we made a powerful alliance and put him down.

315.speaker: Jaheira
315.text: But he's returned. Not only does General Ketheric Thorm live again, it seems he is no longer mortal. He has become, in fact, invincible.

464.speaker: Jaheira
464.text: We met him on the road here - commanding an army of the Absolute, intent on destroying Baldur's Gate. I put an arrow through his eye myself, only to watch him pluck it out like a splinter.

216.speaker: Jaheira
216.text: He healed right in front of me, and chased us into the shadows. Things looked hopeless, but experience has taught me that no matter how bleak things look, there's always hope.

185.speaker: Player
185.text: It's rare people look at me and see 'hope'.

442.speaker: Player
442.text: I'm trying my best to be...

358.speaker: Player
358.text: Ketheric's power stems from a relic in a Sharran temple: his pet necromancer is trying to reach it.

97.speaker: Player
97.text: Ketheric's power stems from the Nightsong -  a relic which his necromancer, Balthazar, is trying to reach.

156.speaker: Jaheira
156.text: You've learned so much? That tadpole in your head already begins to pay dividends.

418.speaker: Jaheira
418.text: This relic must be your focus instead, then. Find it. Strip him of its power.

429.speaker: Player
429.text: What do you have in mind?

109.speaker: Player
109.text: You think I can kill him?

154.speaker: Player
154.text: It's rare people look at me and see 'hope'.

314.speaker: Jaheira
314.text: The light is rather dim, out here in the shadowlands. The point remains:

19.speaker: Player
19.text: Hope is an illusion - one easily shattered. I deal in action, so tell me - what's the plan?

288.speaker: Player
288.text: Hope is my speciality. How can I help?

89.speaker: Player
89.text: Invincible? Please - let's see how he deals with decapitation.

34.speaker: Jaheira
34.text: The same way he dealt with my arrow in his eye, I suspect. Much as I share your desire for a simple life - we must try another way.

66.speaker: Player
66.text: Invincibility? That's powerful magic - thankfully, I have my own.

77.speaker: Jaheira
77.text: And the wit to know when it will not avail you, I think. We must try another way.

210.speaker: Player
210.text: If we can discover the source of his immortality... why, the potential is endless.

18.speaker: Jaheira
18.text: There is only one outcome that interests me - killing Ketheric Thorm, and ensuring that it sticks this time.

188.speaker: Jaheira
188.text: Protected by your artefact, you can infiltrate his forces at Moonrise Towers, posing as a True Soul.

230.speaker: Jaheira
230.text: Find out what it is that makes him invincible so we can strip him of his advantage.

232.speaker: Jaheira
232.text: Once Ketheric is without his shield, the sword: together we assault his tower, and put a final end to this blight.

195.speaker: Player
195.text: I'll taste of the General's blood before all of this is done.

390.speaker: Jaheira
390.text: I appreciate your enthusiasm. Just be sure it doesn't make you leap before you look.
390.context: NodeContext: Remaining serious, but with warmth in her voice (she's referring to Minsc)

334.speaker: Jaheira
334.text: Infiltrate the Towers, and Ketheric's downfall begins. What's more - you'll find the cure for that thing in your head.

246.speaker: Player
246.text: Ketheric's days are numbered - I'll make sure of it.

263.speaker: Jaheira
263.text: Without a cure for your infection, your days are numbered too, yet you selflessly offer to spend them fighting alongside us. I like you.

148.speaker: Jaheira
148.text: I promise I will do everything I can to make sure you survive this.

395.speaker: Player
395.text: You want to make use of my infection - I want to be cured of it.

35.speaker: Player
35.text: Seems like I'll be doing most of the heavy lifting.

47.speaker: Jaheira
47.text: You're the only one who can get inside the Towers. You were born for this mission - or made for it, rather.

83.speaker: Jaheira
83.text: Besides, you need this. You need to heal yourself of your infection.

293.speaker: Jaheira
293.text: Any cure starts with understanding the disease.

69.speaker: Jaheira
69.text: Whatever magic Ketheric's using to control these tadpoles, it must be at Moonrise.

372.speaker: Jaheira
372.text: Until then, we'll keep drinking wine when we meet.

52.speaker: Jaheira
52.text: Before you go, there's somebody else you should meet.

433.speaker: Jaheira
433.text: You're not our only secret weapon.

331.speaker: Jaheira
331.text: Isobel - a faithful cleric of Selûne, and a light in the darkness.

247.speaker: Jaheira
247.text: She cast the moon shield around the inn. It's the only reason we're still alive.

171.speaker: Jaheira
171.text: She's upstairs in her chambers. Tell her I sent you and she'll see you through the shadows safely.

122.speaker: Player
122.text: I already have a lantern that protects me from the darkness.

266.speaker: Jaheira
266.text: I'm sure it's very fine. But lanterns have a tricky habit of going out when you need them.

384.speaker: Jaheira
384.text: Let's not spurn what few gifts the gods choose to give us, hm?

289.speaker: Player
289.text: How do I reach him? The Towers are surrounded by shadows.

261.speaker: Player
261.text: A solid plan. Except it puts me right in the line of fire.

281.speaker: Player
281.text: I've already discovered the source of Ketheric's invulnerability: a celestial called the Nightsong.

88.speaker: Jaheira
88.text: What?! So all this time, he has been leeching his life from an immortal? The man is more parasite than that thing in your head.

259.speaker: Jaheira
259.text: Well done. Did you learn how we might untether Ketheric from this Nightsong?

285.speaker: Player
285.text: No. I sent the Nightsong back to Ketheric.

406.speaker: Jaheira
406.text: 'Sent'? Meaning you had the source of all of Ketheric's power in your grasp, and you gave it back to him?

470.speaker: Jaheira
470.text: Why would you take the knife from our enemy's throat? Unless, perhaps, he is not your enemy at all.

217.speaker: Player
217.text: I'm your only hope to infiltrate the cult. You don't get to question how I do it.

328.speaker: Jaheira
328.text: When I asked your aid, I did not think you the type to balance our lives on petty intrigue.

11.speaker: Jaheira
11.text: But... so be it. It is you who has the key to Moonrise, not I. Do what you must - if it rids us of this cult, we'll consider the price well-paid.

302.speaker: Jaheira
302.text: Justify it whatever way you wish. The fact remains that I placed our lives in your hands, and you tossed them down as a wager in some game of your own.

282.speaker: Player
282.text: Don't threaten me. Only one of us has the means to finish Ketheric, and it isn't you.

381.speaker: Player
381.text: How many will die if we storm the tower? This way, I'm welcomed as a hero.

129.speaker: Jaheira
129.text: I had hoped undoing his protection might loosen the shadows' grip on this land, too - give us some means to move against him in force.

111.speaker: Player
111.text: I take the knife from his throat - and then he bares his back for the killing blow.

235.speaker: Jaheira
235.text: And you strike that blow alone.

265.speaker: Player
265.text: Trust me. This way, I get past the tower's defences - straight to the heart of the enemy.

113.speaker: Player
113.text: I don't need to explain myself to you.

276.speaker: Jaheira
276.text: And I do not need to suffer a stranger in our midst, gambling with our very lives without explaining why.

457.speaker: Player
457.text: Ketheric has the knowledge to save me. You're just a ruined old woman hiding in a ruined old inn.

245.speaker: Jaheira
245.text: Such a sharp tongue. Perhaps I'll stuff it in your ear, so you might enjoy your own wit in death.

207.speaker: Jaheira
207.text: I was a fool to trust you. For the last time. Harpers! There's a traitor among us.
207.context: NodeContext: This leads to combat. The call to the Harpers is called out to her troops.

86.speaker: Player
86.text: Remove her from her bonds, or kill her, maybe. I haven't done either.

431.speaker: Jaheira
431.text: Pick one. Whichever is quicker. And do it now.

243.speaker: Jaheira
243.text: Then by all means, don't let me keep you. We can't end this until Ketheric can bleed. I await your next report.

249.speaker: Jaheira
249.text: What?! So all this time, he has been leeching his life from an immortal? The man is more parasite than anything in his True Souls' heads.

354.speaker: Player
354.text: Druids and Harpers reuniting to fight Ketheric once more - it is fitting. We will free this land of him.

131.speaker: Player
131.text: There's something you should know - Marcus, the Flaming Fist upstairs, is a True Soul. He wants to kidnap Isobel.

361.context: CinematicNodeContext: Jaheir takes the glass from the table.

28.speaker: Player
28.text: 'The Glorious True Soul [GEN_PlayerName_c11eee1e-7815-6143-7233-f2427799fa53]' will be the performance of a lifetime.

473.speaker: Jaheira
473.text: Without a cure to your infection, that lifetime might become rather limited.

159.speaker: Player
159.text: If he's back, perhaps you should have hit him harder in the first place.

190.speaker: Jaheira
190.text: Believe me - he was well and truly dead. I locked his corpse in the Thorm mausoleum myself.

342.speaker: Jaheira
342.text: General Ketheric Thorm. Remember that name. He's the leader of the Absolutists.

37.speaker: Jaheira
37.text: It seems likely. Which means he isn't working alone.

348.speaker: Jaheira
348.text: He was a Sharran, once - took to building an army of Dark Justiciars beneath this very village. Alongside the local druids, we made it our business to see him deposed - dead and buried.

346.speaker: Player
346.text: Tales of the undead are often exaggerated. You're sure you killed him?

439.speaker: Player
439.text: What happened to me being the godsend you've been praying for?

400.speaker: Jaheira
400.text: That was a public display of hope, despite private reservations.

138.speaker: Player
138.text: I'm interested in saving my own skin, not yours. Whether you trust me is immaterial.

132.speaker: Jaheira
132.text: I won't begrudge you that. But our interests align, and I hope no loyalty of that thing in your head to the Absolute will interfere with our salvation.

137.speaker: Jaheira
137.text: I've traced people like you, people with parasites in their brains, all the way here from Baldur's Gate.

62.speaker: Player
62.text: Trust doesn't matter. I'll get the job done - that's all you need to know.

229.speaker: Player
229.text: The answer is no. It has no influence on me whatsoever.

13.speaker: Narrator
13.text: *You want to deny the parasite has any sort of hold on you, but somehow you can't. Jaheira spots your confusion and her eyes narrow.*

399.speaker: Jaheira
399.text: It's the wine. I added a herb to your cup that betrays your lie.

316.speaker: Player
316.text: The answer is no. It has no influence on me whatsoever.

280.speaker: Jaheira
280.text: I find that decidedly hard to believe.

2.speaker: Player
2.text: Despite knowing you're under the effects of a drug, try to deny the tadpole has any influence over you.

398.speaker: Player
398.text: I've done so much since the crash, who's to say it's the tadpole that changed me?

460.speaker: Jaheira
460.text: You speak frivolously. I do not believe you grasp the cost of what we're dealing with.
460.context: NodeContext: getting increasingly irate at the player

135.speaker: Player
135.text: The flowing river changes. It is still a river. I am still me.

378.speaker: Jaheira
378.text: But a river can flood and break its banks. If the parasite changes you - tries to break you - could you resist?

153.speaker: Player
153.text: Suppress the truth-compelling drug with your innate magic. Lie to her.

228.speaker: Player
228.text: Cloud your thoughts with your madness. Weave a lie.

162.speaker: Player
162.text: No, but it spoils my trust.

250.speaker: Player
250.text: I prefer using Venian's Breath for interrogations - it doesn't carry a scent.

317.speaker: Jaheira
317.text: Not, but it does leave the subject paralysed. Whatever comes after, I would have you standing on your own two feet.
317.context: NodeContext: Shrugging - she doesn't trust us yet, and we might well come to blows - but she's not an outright murderer.

279.speaker: Player
279.text: Klauthgrass? I suppose I should be grateful you didn't use Venian's Breath.

178.speaker: Jaheira
178.text: A paralysing agent? I do not think we're quite so far gone - yet.

31.speaker: Player
31.text: This is pointless. Unless you've committed a grevious sin, I am no threat to you.

443.speaker: Jaheira
443.text: A noble proclamation. It must have you made you quite thirsty.
443.context: NodeContext: dry, not to be swayed

352.speaker: Player
352.text: Klauthgrass - a rare specimen found in the Moonshae Isles that must be shorn under a full moon. I'm honoured you'd go to such efforts for me.

142.speaker: Jaheira
142.text: You know more of the herb than I do, it seems. Except for how it tastes, perhaps?
142.context: NodeContext: Dry, acknowledging our knowledge that she spiked the wine with a truth-herb, but insisting we drink anyway

179.speaker: Player
179.text: I am prone to dizziness and fainting. Is it safe?

8.speaker: Player
8.text: I'm not always in control of my magic - who knows what will happen if I drink this?

329.speaker: Jaheira
329.text: You will be refreshed, and I will be reassured.

144.speaker: Player
144.text: I was actually wondering if it would affect me. Poisons often struggle.

101.speaker: Jaheira
101.text: Well, consider this an experiment, then.

90.speaker: Jaheira
90.text: You don't know what you're missing.

167.speaker: Narrator
167.text: *You perceive inviting hints of cedar wood and blackberry. Nothing out of the ordinary.*
167.context: CinematicNodeContext: Player raises wine glass to their nose

323.speaker: Jaheira
323.text: I assure you, it's quite safe.

182.speaker: Player
182.text: You'll have to pardon my friend Karlach. She's very excited to meet you.

254.speaker: Karlach
254.text: Tsh. Yeah. I mean, it's an honour. M'lady.
254.context: NodeContext: Player just called her out for being flustered by Jaheira's presence and she's very awkwardly trying to recover face. Curtsies weirdly on 'mlady' like an absolute dork.

341.speaker: Jaheira
341.text: I will gladly drink to your health as well, Karlach.
341.context: NodeContext: Mild amusement at Karlach's display of dorkiness, but still tense since she's trying to get the player to drink a truth serum.

428.speaker: Player
428.text: Jaheira, there's something you need to know: Marcus is a True Soul, and he's planning to kidnap Isobel.

120.speaker: Jaheira
120.text: This place is crawling with Harpers. If Marcus managed to get himself infected, we would've known the same minute.

220.speaker: Jaheira
220.text: Is this some kind of test? Or a game, perhaps?

321.speaker: Player
321.text: Absolutely not. Marcus is a danger to you all.

296.speaker: Jaheira
296.text: Let's be discreet about this. If Marcus is what you say, there's no telling what kind of reinforcements he might be able to summon.
296.context: NodeContext: Lowerign voice. She believes the player that Marcus is a spy.

322.speaker: Jaheira
322.text: All right. He's in Isobel's room upstairs. Play along with his ruse for now while I gather a few trusted Harpers - but don't let him get his hands on Isobel!

38.speaker: Jaheira
38.text: You did well bringing this to me - thank you.

65.speaker: Jaheira
65.text: A Harper's gaze can only be turned by proof. By the looks of it, a tall tale is all you have to offer.

50.speaker: Jaheira
50.text: But you're far from the most eccentric drinking companion I've had. I'd like to know more. Cheers.
50.context: CinematicNodeContext: She indicates the wine on the table.

203.speaker: Jaheira
203.text: You might be... eccentric, but you're still our best hope of finishing off Ketheric Thorm.

301.speaker: Player
301.text: I have proof, if you'll just come upstairs and look.

130.speaker: Player
130.text: Ignore me, then. It's your own funeral.

340.speaker: Jaheira
340.text: I'm not ignoring you - I just see no evidence of your rather outlandish claim.

146.speaker: Jaheira
146.text: You've come from the shadows and wasted no time accusing one of our companions of treason. It's all a little... odd.

260.speaker: Player
260.text: No, to yours. You don't know what it means to me to meet you.

297.speaker: Jaheira
297.text: It means you've found an old woman down to her last idea - drinking with a mind flayer's infectee.

145.speaker: Jaheira
145.text: Please - drink. You'll tolerate what I have to say better after a glass or two.

59.speaker: Player
59.text: And I'll drink to the darkness that will soon fall when I drag Isobel all the way to Moonrise Towers.

104.speaker: Jaheira
104.context: CinematicNodeContext: Jaheira puts down her wine glass, looking alarmed.

115.speaker: Player
115.text: Meet her stare head on as you examine her body language.

376.speaker: Narrator
376.text: *She is anxious for you to drink the wine first - and it's an anxiety you recognise.*

82.speaker: Narrator
82.text: *Not every knave prefers a blade in the ribs or arrow in the back. Some prefer poison.*

292.speaker: Player
292.text: If I drink this, how long before the poison you've added kills me?

68.speaker: Jaheira
68.text: Well spotted, but if I wanted you dead, I'd have crushed you with my vines.

435.speaker: Jaheira
435.text: I've only added a touch of Klauthgrass - a quaint herb that encourages truth-telling.

202.speaker: Player
202.text: Sniff the wine to see if it's been tampered with.

438.speaker: Jaheira
438.text: The shadows haven't consumed you. Good.
438.context: NodeContext: Surveying us, happy to see us

AD_PlayersAttackJaheira_0.speaker: Jaheira
AD_PlayersAttackJaheira_0.text: Harpers, to me! We have a True Soul to crush.
